Simplified Multicast Forwarding
Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: This document describes a Simplified Multicast Forwarding (SMF) mechanism that provides basic Internet Protocol (IP) multicast forwarding suitable for limited wireless mesh and mobile ad hoc network (MANET) use. It is mainly applicable in situations where efficient flooding represents an acceptable engineering design trade-off. It defines techniques for multicast duplicate packet detection (DPD), to be applied in the forwarding process, for both IPv4 and IPv6 protocol use. This document also specifies optional mechanisms for using reduced relay sets to achieve more efficient multicast data distribution within a mesh topology as compared to Classic Flooding. Interactions with other protocols, such as use of information provided by concurrently running unicast routing protocols or interaction with other multicast protocols, as well as multiple deployment approaches are also described. Distributed algorithms for selecting reduced relay sets and related discussion are provided in the appendices. Basic issues relating to the operation of multicast MANET border routers are discussed, but ongoing work remains in this area and is beyond the scope of this document.

1. Introduction and Scope
contents.ja: 1.はじめと範囲

contents.text: Unicast routing protocols, designed for MANET and wireless mesh use, often apply distributed algorithms to flood routing control plane messages within a MANET routing domain. For example, algorithms specified within [RFC3626] and [RFC3684] provide distributed methods of dynamically electing reduced relay sets that attempt to efficiently flood routing control messages while maintaining a connected set under dynamic topological conditions.
contents.ja: MANETと無線メッシュ使用するために設計されたユニキャストルーティングプロトコルは、多くの場合、MANETルーティングドメイン内の制御プレーンメッセージをルーティング氾濫する分散アルゴリズムを適用します。例えば、[RFC3626]内で指定されたアルゴリズムと[RFC3684]は、動的に効率よく動的トポロジー条件下接続セットを維持しつつ、制御メッセージをルーティングフラッディングを試みる低減リレーセットを選出の分散方法を提供します。

contents.text: Simplified Multicast Forwarding (SMF) extends the efficient flooding concept to the data forwarding plane, providing an appropriate multicast forwarding capability for use cases where localized, efficient flooding is considered an effective design approach. The baseline design is intended to provide a basic, best-effort multicast forwarding capability that is constrained to operate within a single MANET routing domain.
contents.ja: 簡略化されたマルチキャスト転送（SMF）ローカライズされた、効率的なフラッディングは、効果的な設計手法であると考えられるユースケースに適したマルチキャスト転送機能を提供する、平面を転送するデータへの効率的なフラッディングの概念を拡張します。ベースラインの設計は、単一のMANETのルーティングドメイン内で動作するように制約されている基本的な、ベストエフォート型マルチキャスト転送機能を提供することを意図しています。

3. Applicability Statement
contents.ja: 3.適用性に関する声明

contents.text: Within dynamic wireless routing topologies, maintaining traditional forwarding trees to support a multicast routing protocol is often not as effective as in wired networks due to the reduced reliability and increased dynamics of mesh topologies [MGL04][GM99]. A basic packet forwarding service reaching all connected routers running the SMF protocol within a MANET routing domain may provide a useful group communication paradigm for various classes of applications, for example, multimedia streaming, interactive group-based messaging and applications, peer-to-peer middleware multicasting, and multi-hop mobile discovery or registration services. SMF is likely only appropriate for deployment in limited dynamic MANET routing domains (further defined as administratively scoped multicast forwarding domains in Section 9.2) so that the flooding process can be contained.
contents.ja: 動的無線ルーティングトポロジ内で、マルチキャストルーティングプロトコルをサポートするために、従来の転送ツリーを維持することはしばしば信頼性の低下及びメッシュトポロジ[MGL04]の増加ダイナミクス[GM99]に有線ネットワークにおけるほど有効ではありません。 MANETルーティングドメイン内SMFプロトコルを実行しているすべての接続されたルータは、ピア・ツー・ピア、例えば、マルチメディアストリーミング、インタラクティブグループベースのメッセージングアプリケーション、アプリケーションの様々なクラスの有用なグループ通信パラダイムを提供することが到達基本的なパケット転送サービスミドルウェアマルチキャスト、およびマルチホップモバイル発見または登録サービスを提供しています。 SMFは、おそらくフラッディング処理が含まれることができるように、限られたダイナミックMANETルーティングドメインに配備（さらに9.2節と同様に管理スコープマルチキャスト転送ドメインを定義する）ためにのみ適切です。

contents.text: A design goal is that hosts may also participate in multicast traffic transmission and reception with standard IP network-layer semantics (e.g., special or unnecessary encapsulation of IP packets should be avoided in this case). SMF deployments are able to connect and interoperate with existing standard multicast protocols operating within more conventional Internet infrastructures. To this end, a multicast border router or proxy mechanism MUST be used when deployed alongside more fixed-infrastructure IP multicast routing such Protocol Independent Multicast (PIM) variants [RFC3973][RFC4601]. Experimental SMF implementations and deployments have demonstrated gateway functionality at MANET border routers operating with existing external IP multicast routing protocols [CDHM07][DHS08][DHG09]. SMF may be extended or combined with other mechanisms to provide increased reliability and group-specific filtering; the details for this are out of the scope of this document.
contents.ja: 設計目標は、（例えば、IPパケットの特殊な又は不要なカプセル化は、この場合には避けるべきである）ホストは、標準のIPネットワーク層のセマンティクスとマルチキャストトラフィックの送受信に関与する可能性があることです。 SMFの展開は、接続して、より多くの従来のインターネットインフラストラクチャ内で動作する既存の標準のマルチキャストプロトコルと相互運用することができます。一緒に複数の固定インフラIPマルチキャストルーティングのようなプロトコル独立マルチキャスト（PIM）は、変異体[RFC3973]、[RFC4601]を展開すると、この端部に、マルチキャスト境界ルータまたはプロキシメカニズムを使用しなければなりません。実験的なSMFの実装と展開は、既存の外部IPマルチキャストルーティングプロトコルで動作するMANET境界ルータでゲートウェイ機能を実証している[CDHM07] [DHS08] [DHG09]。 SMFは、高い信頼性とグループ固有のフィルタリングを提供するために、拡張または他のメカニズムと組み合わせることができます。このため詳細はこの文書の範囲外です。

contents.text: Certain IP multicast packets, defined in Sections 9.2 and 5, are "non-forwardable". These multicast packets MUST be ignored by the SMF forwarding engine. The SMF forwarding engine MAY also work with policies and management interfaces to allow additional filtering control over which multicast packets are considered for potential SMF forwarding. This interface would allow more refined dynamic forwarding control once such techniques are matured for MANET operation. At present, further discussion of dynamic control is left to future work.
contents.ja: セクション9.2および5で定義された特定のIPマルチキャストパケットは、「非転送可能」です。これらのマルチキャストパケットは、SMFフォワーディングエンジンによって無視されなければなりません。 SMFフォワーディングエンジンは、マルチキャストパケットが潜在的なSMFの転送のために考慮された上、追加のフィルタリング制御を可能にするためのポリシーおよび管理インターフェイスで動作する可能性があります。そのような技術は、MANET動作熟成されると、このインタフェースは、より洗練された動的な転送制御を可能にします。現時点では、動的制御の更なる議論は今後の作業に委ねられています。

contents.text: Classic Flooding (CF) is defined as the simplest case of SMF multicast forwarding. With CF, all SMF routers forward each received multicast packet exactly once. In this case, the need for any relay set selection or neighborhood topology information is eliminated, at the expense of additional network overhead incurred from unnecessary packet retransmissions. With CF, the SMF DPD functionality is still required. While SMF supports CF as a mode of operation, the use of more efficient relay set modes is RECOMMENDED in order to reduce contention and congestion caused by unnecessary packet retransmissions [NTSC99].
contents.ja: 古典的なフラッディング（CF）は、SMFのマルチキャスト転送の最も簡単な場合として定義されます。 CFでは、すべてのSMFルータは、それぞれが一度だけマルチキャストパケットを受信し転送します。この場合には、任意の中継セット選択または近隣トポロジ情報の必要性は、不要なパケット再送から発生した追加のネットワーク・オーバーヘッドを犠牲にして、排除されます。 CFでは、SMF DPD機能がまだ必要です。 SMFは、動作モードとしてCFをサポートしながら、より効率的な中継セットモードの使用が不要なパケット再送[NTSC99]によって引き起こされる競合と輻輳を軽減するために推奨されます。

contents.text: An efficient reduced relay set is constructed by selecting and updating, as needed, a subset of all possible routers in a MANET routing domain to act as SMF forwarders. Known distributed relay set selection algorithms have demonstrated the ability to provide and maintain a dynamic connected set for forwarding multicast IP packets [MDC04]. A few such relay set selection algorithms are described in the appendices of this document, and the basic designs borrow directly from previously documented IETF work. SMF relay set configuration is extensible, and additional relay set algorithms beyond those specified here can be accommodated in future work.
contents.ja: 効率的な縮小リレーセットは、必要に応じてSMFフォワーダとして機能するように、MANETルーティングドメイン内の全ての可能なルータのサブセットを選択して更新することにより構成されています。公知の分散中継設定選択アルゴリズムは、マルチキャストIPパケット[MDC04]を転送するための動的接続されたセットを提供し、維持する能力を実証しています。いくつかのように、リレーセット選択アルゴリズムは、この文書の付録に記載されており、基本的なデザインは、以前に文書化IETF仕事から直接借ります。 SMFリレーセットの構成は拡張可能であり、そしてここで指定したもの以外の追加のリレーセットアルゴリズムは、将来の仕事に収容することができます。

contents.text: Determining and maintaining an optimized set of relays generally requires dynamic neighborhood topology information. Neighborhood topology discovery functions MAY be provided by a MANET unicast routing protocol or by using the MANET Neighborhood Discovery Protocol (NHDP) [RFC6130], operating concurrently with SMF. This specification also allows alternative lower-layer interfaces (e.g., radio router interfaces) to provide the necessary neighborhood information to aid in supporting more effective relay set selection. An SMF implementation SHOULD provide the ability for multicast forwarding state to be dynamically managed per operating network interface. contents.text: Duplicate packet detection (DPD) is often a requirement in MANET or wireless mesh packet forwarding mechanisms because packets may be transmitted out via the same physical interface as the one over which they were received. Routers may also receive multiple copies of the same packets from different neighbors or interfaces. SMF operation requires DPD, and implementations MUST provide mechanisms to detect and reduce the likelihood of forwarding duplicate multicast packets using temporal packet identification. It is RECOMMENDED this be implemented by keeping a history of recently processed multicast packets for comparison with incoming packets. A DPD packet cache history SHOULD be kept long enough so as to span the maximum network traversal lifetime, MAX_PACKET_LIFETIME, of multicast packets being forwarded within an SMF routing domain. The DPD mechanism SHOULD avoid keeping unnecessary state for packet flows such as those that are locally generated or link-local destinations that would not be considered for forwarding, as presented in Section 5.

contents.text: A default hash-based DPD approach (H-DPD) for use by SMF is specified as follows. An SHA-1 [RFC3174] hash of the non-mutable header fields, options fields, and data content of the IPv6 multicast packet is used to produce a 160-bit digest. The approach for calculating this hash value SHOULD follow the same guidelines described for calculating the Integrity Check Value (ICV) described in [RFC4302] with respect to non-mutable fields. This approach should have a reasonably low probability of digest collision when packet headers and content are varying. SHA-1 is being applied in SMF only to provide a low probability of collision and is not being used for cryptographic or authentication purposes. A history of the packet hash values SHOULD be maintained within the context of the IPv6 packet header <srcAddr>. SMF ingress points (i.e., source hosts or gateways) use this history to confirm that new packets are unique with respect to their hash value. The hash assist value (HAV) field described in Section 6.1.1 is provided as a differentiating field when a digest collision would otherwise occur. Note that the HAV is an immutable option field, and SMF MUST process any included HAV values (see Section 6.1.1) in its hash calculation.

contents.text: The Message TLV type denoted SMF_TYPE is used to identify the existence of an SMF instance operating in conjunction with NHDP. This information can be used to take action, such as ignoring neighbor information using incompatible algorithms. It is possible that SMF neighbors MAY be configured differently and still operate cooperatively, but these cases will vary dependent upon the algorithm types designated.

contents.text: 9.1. Forwarded Multicast Groups

contents.text: Mechanisms for dynamically determining groups for forwarding into a MANET SMF routing domain is an evolving technology area. Ideally, only traffic for which there is active group membership should be injected into the SMF domain. This can be accomplished by providing an IPv4 Internet Group Membership Protocol (IGMP) or IPv6 Multicast Listener Discovery (MLD) proxy protocol so that MANET SMF routers can inform attached border routers (and hence multicast networks) of their current group membership status. For specific systems and services, it may be possible to statically configure group membership joins in border routers, but it is RECOMMENDED that some form of IGMP/MLD proxy or other explicit, dynamic control of membership be provided. Specification of such an IGMP/MLD proxy protocol is beyond the scope of this document.

contents.text: The need for the border router to receive traffic from recognized multicast sources within the SMF routing domain is important to achieve interoperability with some existing routing protocols. contents.text: A potential denial-of-service attack against SMF forwarding is possible when a malicious router has a form of wormhole access to non-adjacent parts of a network topology. In the wireless ad hoc case, a directional antenna is one way to provide such a wormhole physically. If such a router can preview forwarded packets in a non-adjacent part of the network and forward modified versions to another part of the network, it can perform the following attack. The malicious router could reduce the TTL/hop limit or hop limit of the packet and transmit it to the SMF router causing it to forward the packet with a limited TTL/hop limit (or even drop it) and make a DPD entry that could block or limit the subsequent forwarding of later-arriving valid packets with correct TTL/hop limit values. This would be a relatively low-cost, high-payoff attack that would be hard to detect and thus attractive to potential attackers. An approach of caching TTL/hop limit information with DPD state and taking appropriate forwarding actions is identified in Section 5 to mitigate this form of attack.

contents.text: Sequence-based packet identifiers are predictable and thus provide an opportunity for a DoS attack against forwarding. Forwarding protocols that use DPD techniques, such as SMF, may be vulnerable to DoS attacks based on spoofing packets with apparently valid packet identifier fields. In wireless environments, where SMF will most likely be used, the opportunity for such attacks may be more prevalent than in wired networks. In the case of IPv4 packets, fragmented IP packets, or packets with IPsec headers applied, the DPD "identifier portions" of potential future packets that might be forwarded is highly predictable and easily subject to DoS attacks against forwarding. A RECOMMENDED technique to counter this concern is for SMF implementations to generate an "internal" hash value that is concatenated with the explicit I-DPD packet identifier to form a unique identifier that is a function of the packet content as well as the visible identifier. SMF implementations could seed their hash generation with a random value to make it unlikely that an external observer could guess how to spoof packets used in a denial-of-service attack against forwarding. Since the hash computation and state is kept completely internal to SMF routers, the cryptographic properties of this hashing would not need to be extensive and thus possibly of low complexity. Experimental implementations may determine that even a lightweight hash of only portions of packets may suffice to serve this purpose.

contents.text: Appendix A. Essential Connecting Dominating Set (E-CDS) Algorithm
contents.ja: 付録A.エッセンシャルの接続支配集合（E-CDS）アルゴリズム

contents.text: The "Essential Connected Dominating Set" (E-CDS) algorithm [RFC5614] forms a single CDS mesh for the SMF operating region. It allows routers to use 2-hop neighborhood topology information to dynamically perform relay self-election to form a CDS. Its packet-forwarding rules are not dependent upon previous hop knowledge. Additionally, E-CDS SMF forwarders can be easily mixed without problems with CF SMF forwarders, even those not participating in NHDP. Another benefit is that packets opportunistically received from non-symmetric neighbors may be forwarded without compromising flooding efficiency or correctness. Furthermore, multicast sources not participating in NHDP may freely inject their traffic, and any neighboring E-CDS relays will properly forward the traffic. The E-CDS-based relay set selection algorithm is based upon [RFC5614]. E-CDS was originally discussed in the context of forming partial adjacencies and efficient flooding for MANET OSPF extensions work, and the core algorithm is applied here for SMF.
contents.ja: 「必須接続支配集合」（E-CDS）アルゴリズム[RFC5614]は、単一のCDSがSMF運転領域用のメッシュが形成されます。これはルータが動的にCDSを形成するために、リレー自己選択を実行するために2ホップ隣接トポロジ情報を使用することを可能にします。そのパケット転送ルールは、前のホップの知識に依存しません。また、E-CDS SMFフォワーダもそれらNHDPに参加していない、CF SMFフォワーダの問題なしに容易に混合することができます。別の利点は、日和見非対称近隣から受信したパケットがフラッディング効率や正確さを犠牲にすることなく転送することができることです。また、マルチキャストソースは自由にトラフィックを注入できるNHDPに参加していない、任意の隣接するE-CDSリレーが正常トラフィックを転送します。 E-CDSベースリレーセット選択アルゴリズムは[RFC5614]に基づいています。 E-CDSは、もともとMANET OSPF拡張作業のための部分的な隣接かつ効率的なフラッディングを形成するの文脈で議論された、コアアルゴリズムは、SMFのためにここで適用されます。

contents.text: A.1. E-CDS Relay Set Selection Overview
contents.ja: A.1。 E-CDSリレーセットの選択の概要

contents.text: The E-CDS relay set selection requires 2-hop neighborhood information collected through NHDP or another process. Relay routers, in E-CDS SMF selection, are "self-elected" using a Router Identifier (Router ID) and an optional nodal metric, referred to here as Router Priority for all 1-hop and 2-hop neighbors. To ensure proper relay set self-election, the Router ID and Router Priority MUST be consistent among participating routers. It is RECOMMENDED that NHDP be used to share Router ID and Router Priority through the use of SMF_TYPE:E-CDS TLVs as described in this appendix. The Router ID is a logical identification that MUST be consistent across interoperating SMF neighborhoods, and it is RECOMMENDED to be chosen as the numerically largest address contained in a router's "Neighbor Address List" as defined in NHDP. The E-CDS self-election process can be summarized as follows:
contents.ja: E-CDSのリレーのセットの選択は、NHDP又は他のプロセスを通じて収集2ホップ近隣情報が必要となります。 E-CDS SMF選択における中継ルータは、「自己選出された」ルータ識別子（ルータID）および任意のノードのメトリックを使用しては、全ての1ホップ及び2ホップネイバーのルータ優先度としてここで呼ばれます。適切なリレー設定自己選挙を確保するために、ルータIDとルータの優先順位は、参加ルータ間で一致している必要があります。 NHDPがSMF_TYPEの使用を介してルータIDとルータプライオリティを共有するために使用することをお勧めします。E-CDS TLVをこの付録に記載されているように。ルータIDは、SMFの地域を相互運用全体で一貫していなければならない論理的な識別され、そしてNHDPで定義されているルータの「ネイバーアドレス一覧」に含まれる数値の最大アドレスとして選択することをお勧めします。次のようにE-CDS自己選挙プロセスは、要約することができます。

contents.text: 1. If an SMF router has a higher ordinal (Router Priority, Router ID) than all of its symmetric neighbors, it elects itself to act as a forwarder for all received multicast packets.
contents.ja: 1. SMFルータがその対称近隣のすべてより高い序（ルータプライオリティ、ルータID）を有する場合、それはすべての受信されたマルチキャストパケットの転送機能として作用するように自分自身を選出。

contents.text: 2. Else, if there does not exist a path from the neighbor with largest (Router Priority, Router ID) to any other neighbor, via neighbors with larger values of (Router Priority, Router ID), then it elects itself to the relay set.
contents.ja: そうでなければ2、（ルータプライオリティ、ルータID）のより大きな値を有する近隣を介して、他の隣接する最大（ルータプライオリティ、ルータID）とのネイバーからのパスが存在しない場合、それは、リレーセットに自分自身を選出。

contents.text: The basic form of E-CDS described and applied within this specification does not provide for redundant relay set selection (e.g., bi-connected), but such capability is supported by the basic E-CDS design.
contents.ja: 本明細書内に記載され、適用されるE-CDSの基本的な形態は、（例えば、双方向接続）冗長中継セット選択のために提供していないが、そのような機能は、基本的なE-CDS設計によってサポートされています。

contents.text: A.2. E-CDS Forwarding Rules
contents.ja: A.2。 E-CDS転送ルール

contents.text: With E-CDS, any SMF router that has selected itself as a relay performs DPD and forwards all non-duplicative multicast traffic allowed by the present forwarding policy. Packet previous-hop knowledge is not needed for forwarding decisions when using E-CDS.
contents.ja: E-CDSと、リレーとしての地位を選択した任意のSMFルータはDPDと現在転送ポリシーで許可されて前方にすべての非重複マルチキャストトラフィックを行います。 E-CDSを使用した場合、パケット前ホップ知識は、転送の決定のために必要とされません。

contents.text: 1. Upon packet reception, DPD is performed. Note E-CDS requires a single duplicate table for the set of interfaces associated with the relay set selection.
contents.ja: パケットを受信する1は、DPDが行われます。 E-CDS注中継セット選択に関連付けられたインターフェイスのセットに対して単一重複テーブルを必要とします。

contents.text: 2. If the packet is a duplicate, no further action is taken.
contents.ja: 2.パケットが重複している場合、それ以上のアクションは取られません。

contents.text: 3. If the packet is non-duplicative:
contents.ja: 3.パケットが非重複の場合：

contents.text: A. A DPD entry is made for the packet identifier.
contents.ja: A. A DPDエントリは、パケット識別子のために作られています。

contents.text: B. The packet is forwarded out to all interfaces associated with the relay set selection.
contents.ja: B.は、パケットが中継セット選択に関連付けられたすべてのインターフェイスに出て転送されます。

contents.text: As previously mentioned, even packets sourced (or relayed) by routers not participating in NHDP and/or the E-CDS relay set selection may be forwarded by E-CDS forwarders without problem. contents.text: Appendix B. Source-Based Multipoint Relay (S-MPR) Algorithm
contents.ja: 付録B.ソースベースのマルチリレー（S-MPR）アルゴリズム

contents.text: The source-based multipoint relay (S-MPR) set selection algorithm enables individual routers, using 2-hop topology information, to select relays from their set of neighboring routers. Relays are selected so that forwarding to the router's complete 2-hop neighbor set is covered. This distributed relay set selection technique has been shown to approximate a minimal connected dominating set (MCDS) in [JLMV02]. Individual routers must collect 2-hop neighborhood information from neighbors, determine an appropriate current relay set, and inform selected neighbors of their relay status. Note that since each router picks its neighboring relays independently, S-MPR forwarders depend upon previous hop information (e.g., source MAC address) to operate correctly. The Optimized Link State Routing (OLSR) protocol has used this algorithm and protocol for relay of link state updates and other control information [RFC3626], and it has been demonstrated operationally in dynamic network environments.

contents.text: B.1. S-MPR Relay Set Selection Overview

contents.text: The S-MPR algorithm uses bi-directional 1-hop and 2-hop neighborhood information collected via NHDP to select, from a router's 1-hop neighbors, a set of relays that will cover the router's entire 2-hop neighbor set upon forwarding. The algorithm described uses a "greedy" heuristic of first picking the 1-hop neighbor who will cover the most 2-hop neighbors. Then, excluding those 2-hop neighbors that have been covered, additional relays from its 1-hop neighbor set are iteratively selected until the entire 2-hop neighborhood is covered. Note that 1-hop neighbors also identified as 2-hop neighbors are considered as 1-hop neighbors only.

contents.text: The MPR-CDS relay set selection process is based upon the MPR selection process of the S-MPR algorithm with the added refinement of a distributed technique for subsequently down-selecting to a common reduced, shared relay set. contents.text: C.4. MPR-CDS Selection Algorithm
contents.ja: C.4。 MPR-CDS選択アルゴリズム

contents.text: This section describes an algorithm for the MPR-CDS selection process. Note that the selection described is with respect to a specific interface of the router performing selection, and other router interfaces referenced are reachable from this reference router interface. An ordered tuple of Router Priority and Router ID is used in MPR-CDS relay set selection. The Router ID value should be set to the largest advertised address of a given router; this information is provided to one-hop neighbors via NHDP by default. Precedence is given to the Router Priority portion, and the Router ID value is used as a tiebreaker. The evaluation of this tuple is referred to as "RtrPri(n)" in the description below where "n" references a specific router. Note that it is possible that the Router Priority portion may be optional and the evaluation of "RtrPri()" be solely based upon the unique Router ID. Since there MUST NOT be any duplicate address values among SMF routers, a comparison of "RtrPri(n)" between any two routers will always be an inequality.
